content.description: We disagree with MP.com poster Tony B.as to his characterization of this rock climb. He must be misguided. Indeed this is a strenuous  5.10 handcrack with a spicy traverse in from the right, a good climb. Sling a ridgetop flake for a belay and do a 2nd "low 5th chimney and ridge pitch northward to a bolted anchor. Rap to the north.
content.location:
Just to the right of

Hanging Tree

is an obvious, right-facing corner. Begin at a fine spot right of the corner and approach the corner from the right.

content.description: This is a good, hard pitch with most crack sizes represented. I found it to be a bona fide Kimball sandbag at 11a that felt more like mid to hard 5.11. The bottom section is hands, if I remember right, the middle section involves some tips jamming and thin face moves (this is where I whipped out of it),  and the upper part is fists to chimney. The transition out of the middle section was hard and a bit spooky as well.
content.protection: Standard rack / RPs and small cams.
content.location:
This pitch is on the skinny East face of the crag. A  crack line comprised of three sections separated by horizontals leads to the summit.

Scramble down the Southeast corner of the formation.

climbs.name: Mission Creep
climbs.fa: description etc.: Pale Dale & Nate A., 2011

content.description:
You have a choice:

P1. Climb a short finger crack or just to the right climb a cornercrack, both are good 5.9. Above either crack, move around into a wide groove and belay from a stainless steel wire sling, slung over a fin/flake.

P2. Worm through a low 5th class chimney and scramble 100 feet  westward to

Bush Doctrine's

anchors.
content.location:
This is located 150 feet right of

Hanging Tree

under a prominant, left-facing dihedral.

It is north-facing.

content.description: Aim for the tree growing out of the cliff at the base of a left-leaning splitter. Traverse in from the left in a right-angling, intermittent, crack system. I vaguely remember the traversing start to be slightly dirty and a wee bit spicy, but the jamming in the upper crack is well worth the effort.
content.location:
Pretty much dead center on the North Face of the crag is a tree growing out of the base of a left-leaning crack. Start the pitch down and left where a weakness heads right toward the tree.

Walk / scramble down the Southeast corner of the crag.

content.description:
Varied and exciting, this new route weaves its way around several bushes in the center of Out West Crag's north face.

Start nicely  with a fingertip traverse past 3 solid knifeblades then go up a groove to a stance beneath a bolt. Climb past the bolt and a thimbleberry clump to finish with a strenuous offwidth move (#5 or 6 cam protect this). Alternately, avoid the bolt step left and handjam a pretty, slanting crack to the same finish.

Rap from 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: Trad with a few clips as stated.
